data.title: intellisense stops working after a while in Linux
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Fedora 26

I'm using vscode to write Python and Go using the recommended extensions, after working for a while the intellisense suddenly stops working and every time I had to restart vscode to get a working intellisense again. This is a persistent issue for a while now

This issue can be reproduced in Ubuntu 16.04, Arch, Fedora 25, 26
And this issue was there also into 1.13 version

data.title: No json schema for token color customizations
data.body:

1. Try adding configuration by typing `"editor.tokenColorCustom"`.
2. Press tab when configuration name found as long as you type.

data.title: Search viewlet can take highlighted text at inappropriate times
data.body:
- Open search viewlet
- Have some text in the query input box
- Highlight some portion of a line in the editor
- Have focus in the search viewlet
- Press cmd+shift+j to toggle the search query details area
- :bug: Now the search input box unexpectedly has the selected text

Anything that calls `SearchViewlet.focus()` will do the same. I think that should only happen when focus was originally in the editor.

Long-standing bug.

data.title: Search results file abbreviations can be confusing when searching other folders
data.body:
Mainly the search results don't make a necessary distinction between multi-root mode, and multi-folder searching. They need to show a results node for each folder searched, not for each root folder present.

Examples:

- Single-root mode. Search with include=/foo/bar. The results show in a flat list.

- Multi-root mode. Search with include=/foo/bar. The results show in a node called "bar". These two cases shouldn't be different.

---

- Single-root mode. Search with include=./foo,./bar. The results show in a flat list, and the file path abbreviations are rooted from ./foo and ./bar, and all the results are combined in a flat list, so you can't tell them apart.

- Same in multi-root mode. It gives a node for each folder which is correct.

data.title: Include/exclude precedence for search
data.body: You get different (less correct) results for non-ripgrep search. It will be more difficult to get it right. If this can't be resolved, it should wait for a later release.

data.title: Support excluding ./ and / paths in search viewlet
data.body:
Since it works for include, it should work for exclude. But this doesn't quite fit into the `ISearchQuery` model as-is. 

- Exclude `./root1/folder1`
  - Add another 'exclude' field on the `IFolderQuery`, to keep 'global' excludes that only apply to one folder
- Exclude `/foo/bar`
  - Adapt ripgrep search and fileSearch.ts to detect whether a glob already represents an absolute path

data.title: Inconsistent multi-line regex replace within 1 file vs multiple files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:22:50.650Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
vscode-svgviewer|css|1.4.2
nim|kos|0.5.26
gitblame|wad|2.0.2
clang-format|xav|1.5.0

(1 theme extensions excluded)
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a file containing:
```
hello
  world
```
2. Open "Find in Files" panel.
3. Enter a multiline regex, for example: `o[\s\n]*world`
4. Observe the preview only matches `o`. Try to click "Replace All" and see that only `o` is replaced.
5. Open "Find" panel (for the current file). Enter the same regex. Observe it matches both lines, as expected. Click "Replace" and observe it replaces the whole match, as expected.

![Example](https://i.imgur.com/3tQ8tJ7.png)

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Add support for regular find and replace, rectangular area selection
data.body:
Add support for regular lookups and substitutions
Add support for rectangular area selection. Like Alt + mouse drag in Microsoft Word.

- VSCode Version: 
Version 1.15.0-insider
Commit f21c311e8db9eff11a605b517525aa6c4dd0f09b
Date 2017-07-25T05:10:14.622Z

Extra Notes:

KWin had this problem with several applications, too, but they fixed it here: https://bugs.kde.org/show_bug.cgi?id=344326
Perhaps you can reference their fix when addressing this.

data.title: Alt+F, S doesn't always save

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|bracket-pair-colorizer|CoenraadS|0.10.7|
|sort-typescript-imports|miclo|1.3.0|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.11.0|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.1.6|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Try to save your changes with hotkeys: press "Alt+F" followed by "S".

Expected results: Your changes are saved and you can continue working.

Actual results: The File menu is still showing, changes are not saved, and subsequent keystrokes will be interpreted as File menu hotkeys.

Workaround #1: Press "S" again. 
Workaround #2: Pause briefly after "Alt+F". The "S" will work the first time.

There seems to be a race condition where the "S" keystroke gets swallowed before the File menu is displayed.

Data loss has led me to develop an Alt+F,S twitch over the years - I do that key combination every few minutes, without thinking about it, in all applications, and have done so for more than a decade. I've never run into this obstacle in other applications, and it is kind of aggravating to trip over this every time I use VS Code.

data.title: Issue Opening Folder When Debugging Extension

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
While debugging an extension I execute:
```
vscode.commands.executeCommand('vscode.openFolder', tmpDirUri)
```
The folder is opened in the 'debugging' code instance instead of the 'debug' code instance. Then the 'debug' instance gets shut down because the 'debugging' instance closes on changes folders.

- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run a custom exectension.
2. Execute vscode.commands.executeCommand('vscode.openFolder', tmpDirUri)

data.title: renderer process constantly consumes CPU when background task is running.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:34:09.706Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
ts-tslint|eg2|0.0.4
cpptools|ms-|0.12.1
csharp|ms-|1.11.0
PowerShell|ms-|1.4.1
vscode-icons|rob|7.11.0
cmake|twx|0.0.17



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. I use typescript with `npm: run compile` 2.0 task.
2. When task is not running renderer process is idling.
3. When I run this task, process starts consuming ~10% CPU even if there is no activity, but fan in my Surface Pro 3 starts spinning.
4. When I terminate this task, things get back to normal.

My tasks.json:
```json
{
    "version": "2.0.0",
    "tasks": [
        {
            "type": "npm",
            "script": "compile",
            "problemMatcher": [
                "$tsc-watch"
            ]
        }
    ]
}
```
Here how it looks:
![npm cpu](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7413219/28646039-f73f3984-725f-11e7-8472-4bac31374101.gif)

data.title: Test: Search viewlet changes
data.body:
This covers https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/27226 and https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/29977

- [x] Mac @Lixire 
- [x] Windows @Tyriar 

Complexity: 4

- Try search viewlet in multiroot and non-multiroot mode. The multiroot UI should be usable and make sense. The non-multiroot UI should look the same.
- Try the "Find in Folder" context menu item. In multiroot mode it should use `./` syntax, with the root's basename, in "files to include" unless there is another root folder with the same basename. In that case it should use an absolute path. In single root mode, it should always use `./`
- Try combinations of `./` and glob patterns in "files to include"
- Should get a reasonable error message for `./` and absolute paths that don't exist
- Try different things in include/exclude. Now that the glob buttons are missing, `foo` should match `**/foo,foo/**` (ie, a folder at the root named foo, or all files named foo)
- Don't forget to try things with `"search.useRipgrep": false`.
- Open files should now respect the include/exclude settings

data.title: Git discard changes permanantly deletes files on Linux
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. add new files to a folder/repo
2. undo the pending changes, the newly added files will be permanently deleted from the system

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

I don't know why undo/discarding pending changes using the source control built in to VS Code would permanently delete files on linux as opposed to moving them to the trash bin. Lost a few hundred files thanks to this (though I have a backup as of 6 days ago so I'm not at a complete loss).
